title: How hard is AP US History? - Quora

response.answer_text: It was hard. I remember our first test. Everyone in my class was used to getting easy A’s, so it was a real slap in the face when we got our scores back. We didn’t fail, but most of us got 4’s or lower on our essays, and that was out of 10. My teacher said it was fine and that the first test of the year was always a “bloodbath,” to use her terminology. We just had to get used to doing more work. And I did. I think my average essay score for subsequent tests was a 7 or an 8 during that class. This was probably the hardest class I’ve ever taken, in high school and college. Why? There was a lot of information to memorize, and I mean a lot. My teacher couldn’t stress enough the importance of details. The more you wrote, the better off you were. So, that meant memorizing dates, battles, bills. Everything. By the end of the year, I had filled one notebook with information from lectures and the book and used up half of another one. Just to give you an idea, I typically use less than half of a notebook for each class, so this was a lot for me. I was the type of student who typically got away with studying the night before because I’m good at memorization and that was usually all the time I required to get my A. In this class, I began drilling a week before. There was so much information to learn that I needed to space it out. I got a B in that class and never have I been prouder of a grade. I felt as though I worked myself to the bone and this was the fruit of my labor. Plus, I loved the class and the teacher I took it with ended up being my favorite teacher at the school. I’m a history nerd, so I loved delving deeper into events from the 1800s to the present in the US. If you want to know about the official test, that was a completely different monster. I spent the month before going through my notebooks in my free time, focusing on a few chapters per day, so I didn’t feel as though I was driving myself crazy. I ultimately got a 4 on my test. Not bad! I was expecting a 2.

It's not that hard. If you committ to reading a few chapters in a 2–3 weeks, you should be good. The American Pageant textbook has about 20 pages per chapter. There is a lot of packed information. I got away with reading 2 chapters and the objectives the week of the test. It's easy to read it if you try not to be so bored about it. All I literally have to do in APUSH, is read a few pages per day and review it. Since my teacher never gave a lot of homework, then my APUSH class was easy. All we did in class was “review” so I would just do most of the studying at home. I had a serious interest in it. Along with my textbook, I bought a few other review books and read the same things over again, plus there are so many things online…YouTube videos. Other class APUSH websites. HISTORY | Watch Full Episodes of Your Favorite Shows When I take the tests, I just needed to have test taking skills. Try not to overthink every question and follow your first intuition because it was there for a reason. Make sure you read the question and all the possible answers and then cross off at least 2 and here is the tricky part: you have two answers left and one is them is wrong. You will have to see what makes the most sense. Watch for the word, “all” and be skeptical of statements with the word, “all” in them because it could be wrong. It's mostly reading information and memorizing it for the tests. There are fun review videos and all sorts of study resources. There are Quizlet flashcards to use. Every unit we had a few chapters to read. We would also have a test when we are done reviewing, two short answer questions after the day of the multiple choice and then the long essay that we would turn in ourselves. I found a couple of pdfs online with short answer questions and multiple choice practice tests. Some of the online PDF practice tests for the AP exam had the exact same questions that were on my multiple choice tests! So I could know test answers before the test. It's not cheating if it's online. Jocz Productions makes APUSH studying a little more fun. My way of studying was reading the chapters, finishing the objectives before the test, adding more notes to the outline, and going over things I didn't quite understand. Because I happen to have good memorization skills especially over concepts over things I read, I knew the answers on the test. I don't know what textbook or what teacher your high school may have but my teacher barely gave homework and gave us the American Pageant which is a good textbook because it contains everything you need to know in the chapters and it was a little like a story. The difficulty varies depending on your teacher, how much homework they demand and basically on your abilities to keep up pace with a college level course. If it is your first AP class, figure it out quick and adapt easily and know what you ought to do. I find time alone to read out of the textbook and frankly I enjoy it. You will have to enjoy reading the textbook for the rest of the year. Reading the textbook almost guarantees your knowledge. If you take 30 good minutes to read out of the textbook, a little bit everyday and maybe you could read entire chapters over the WEEKEND, and you love learning about it, you should be good. It just requires a little bit of study effort everyday. Unlike honors classes, which tend to give sheet homework, usually the only homework for APUSH is textbook reading and studying it however you like. It's all up to you. I have a decent B+ in that class and I frankly don't really seem to try. I try to do reading over the weekend. If you do all the reading over the weekend, then you are done! Now during the busy school week, all you got to do is review and do whatever other homework stuff the teacher gives you. Maybe the teacher gives a lot of daily homework, I don't know. APUSH is a good class and it deserves to be recommended for sophomores. It's such a comfortable first AP class to take. At first, you might get a couple D's for your first unit tests, but you can only get better from there. I remember for the first unit test the class average was 69% so a D, but the teacher offered for retakes and gradually as each unit went on, the average increased and we got better at it. Now my highest is a B+ Some units are easier than others. There is a lot of memorization. But what is better about this AP course is that we examine documents. For every unit test there are a few exercepts or “documents” given and you are supposed to apply your knowledge to the interpretation of the excerpt. You will be reading and tested upon things and exercepts from hundreds of years ago and you will have to understand the language well. These documents are noticeably harder to read and we don't just memorize things but we try to understand it. AP is similar to honors, but since there is an AP exam at the end of the AP class, we spend the AP class geared towards the big exam. To take AP, is to get an opportunity to take that exam and possibly earn college credit based off your score. We learn things quicker in AP and assignments are always expected to be done. AP is a more challenging class than honors because the AP exam is hard. The reason why we have to do short answers and long essays is so we practice and prepare for this big exam. The exam has short answers and a long essay that needs to be completed. Whenever you have to do a long essay, try to access it off the rubric so you can get points for your grade. The teacher says she expects us to be reviewing daily. Before people signed up for it, we signed a commitment form that said this AP class may require up to an hour of homework every day. It is highly recommended to keep reviewing the material but I don't really do that. If I just read carefully read the chapters over the weekend and come to class to “review" then I'm good. The reason for my B+ is because it's only October and I just started it, I suspect my grade should get better. It was all only because a few SIMPLE mistakes on my multiple choice test! There was a lot of pressure and I sometimes don't think straight and lose a couple points. Overall, I always do stuff assigned. If you have taken an AP class, you would know better but this is my first and one and only my sophomore year because it's the only one available. AP teachers are far more pickier than honors teachers. They are picky about essays, picky about objectives, they …are…picky! They think they are college teachers, they are not, they are a high school teacher teaching a college course. AP teachers will be glad to take off points for the smallest things. But whatever you get on that test is UP to you! But the teacher is in charge of your grades for everything else. Mind you, I'm STILL taking APUSH. 2019–2020. I might not know what I'm talking about but that's how honest about the class I can get Updated: I got my 2020 score and it is a 3. It's a big reading class that will make you memorize some important details (flashcards) and it is all about understanding history not just knowing all the facts. It is a conceptual class that we learn all the material then connect the dots from one event to another.
